user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemCreate:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemCreate(osal_id_t *sem_id, const char *sem_name, uint32 sem_initial_value, uint32 options)
{
    int32                         return_code;
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    OS_bin_sem_internal_record_t *binsem;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(sem_name);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        binsem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_bin_sem_table, token);

        /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
        OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, binsem, obj_name, sem_name);

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_BinSemCreate_Impl(&token, sem_initial_value, options);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sem_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the fragment itself. The call to OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, &token) does not itself invoke any <string.h> functions, so the fragment alone does not breach Rule 21.17. A possible violation scenario (hypothetical): if sem_name is not a valid NUL-terminated string or points outside its allocated object and OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew internally uses functions like strlen/strcpy/strncpy without proper bounds checking, that internal use could access beyond object bounds and thus violate Rule 21.17.
